user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of find_boundary:
```c
static int
find_boundary (struct MHD_PostProcessor *pp,
               const char *boundary,
               size_t blen,
               size_t *ioffptr,
               enum PP_State next_state,
               enum PP_State next_dash_state)
{
  char *buf = (char *) &pp[1];
  const char *dash;

  if (pp->buffer_pos < 2 + blen)
  {
    if (pp->buffer_pos == pp->buffer_size)
      pp->state = PP_Error;     /* out of memory */
    /* ++(*ioffptr); */
    return MHD_NO;              /* not enough data */
  }
  if ( (0 != memcmp ("--",
                     buf,
                     2)) ||
       (0 != memcmp (&buf[2],
                     boundary,
                     blen)))
  {
    if (pp->state != PP_Init)
    {
      /* garbage not allowed */
      pp->state = PP_Error;
    }
    else
    {
      /* skip over garbage (RFC 2046, 5.1.1) */
      dash = memchr (buf,
                     '-',
                     pp->buffer_pos);
      if (NULL == dash)
        (*ioffptr) += pp->buffer_pos;         /* skip entire buffer */
      else if (dash == buf)
        (*ioffptr)++;                         /* at least skip one byte */
      else
        (*ioffptr) += (size_t) (dash - buf);  /* skip to first possible boundary */
    }
    return MHD_NO;                            /* expected boundary */
  }
  /* remove boundary from buffer */
  (*ioffptr) += 2 + blen;
  /* next: start with headers */
  pp->skip_rn = RN_Dash;
  pp->state = next_state;
  pp->dash_state = next_dash_state;
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (pp->buffer_pos == pp->buffer_size)
      pp->state = PP_Error;     /* out of memory */
explanation: I flagged fragments that are most likely to hide dead or redundant operations and therefore merit investigation: the commented-out increment (possible previously active operation), the assignments to pp->state = PP_Error in two places (they may be redundant or have no effect if state is never observed/used later), the entire garbage-skipping branch that updates *ioffptr in several mutually exclusive ways (some branches may never be exercised), and the final sequence that updates pp->skip_rn/pp->state/pp->dash_state and returns success (these assignments could be redundant if the values are unused). Other parts of the function are not flagged because they clearly affect control flow or are necessary consistency checks: the initial buffer-size check (pp->buffer_pos < 2 + blen) prevents out-of-bounds access; the memcmp checks are the core boundary detection logic and cannot be removed without changing behavior; variable declarations and return statements are essential; the pointer computation char *buf = (char *)&pp[1] is required to access the buffer data following the struct. Those non-flagged fragments therefore do not appear to be dead code and need not be investigated for Rule 2.2 based on the provided function alone.
